intro: Brassica oleracea stirps acephala, commonly known as broccoli, is a cultivar of the cabbage family characterized by its dense, green flower heads. It is native to the Mediterranean region and has been cultivated for centuries for its nutritional value and culinary uses. The plant typically grows to a height of 40–90 cm, with thick, dark green stems and large, waxy leaves. The edible part consists of the unopened flower buds, which are harvested before they fully open. It thrives in cool climates and requires well-drained soil for optimal growth.
